ETYMOLOGY: From Old English sunu, from Proto-Germanic *sunuz (compare Dutch zoon, German Sohn, Swedish son), from Proto-Indo-European *suhnu- (compare Sanskrit sūnu, Lithuanian sūnus, Russian syn).

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) that is used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A male child or person in relation to his parents.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: They have two daughters and one son.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他们有两个女儿和一个儿子。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) that is used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Used as a form of address to a boy or young man, especially by an older person.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: （长者称呼小伙子或男孩时用的爱称或尊称）孩子，小伙子。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: Come here, my son, and tell me what happened.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 过来，孩子，告诉我发生了什么事。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A noun that refers to a specific person, place, or organization, and is usually capitalized.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: In Christian theology, Jesus Christ as the second person of the Trinity.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: （常大写为 Son）在基督教神学中，指圣子，三位一体的第二位（耶稣基督）。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: Christians believe in God the Father, God the Son, and God the Holy Spirit.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 基督徒信仰圣父、圣子和圣灵。

REGISTER: General; formal or specialized in religious contexts
